title: How to Quickly Repair Bathroom Shower Tiles

steps.headline: Purchase tiles that match the old ones.
steps.description: If you know where the existing tiles were purchased, check their store or website for matching tiles. If you’re not sure, look in stores and online to find tiles that match the ones you have as closely as possible. Make sure to measure the tiles before you shop for replacements to ensure that you get the right size.

steps.headline: Put on protective eyewear, hearing protection, gloves, and a respirator.
steps.description: These items are necessary for protecting your eyes, ears, hands, and lungs during this process. It’s also a good idea to wear long sleeves when you’re doing replacing a cracked bathroom tile. You can purchase goggles, ear protection, and a respirator at a hardware store. You can also purchase work gloves. Or, if you have some old canvas or leather gardening gloves, these will work fine.

steps.headline: Scrape grout from the surrounding tiles with an oscillating multi-tool.
steps.description: Hold the rotating blade of the tool against the grout and turn on the tool. Move the blade back and forth over the grout to grind it down. The oscillating multi-tool will grind the grout down to a fine powder that you can easily vacuum or sweep out, so it is the fastest way to remove the grout. If you do not have an oscillating multi-tool, a handheld grout saw or carbide-tipped cutting knife will also work. Use the blades on these tools to saw through and grind down the grout. When you remove the grout, be careful not to cut through any membrane waterproofing underneath or behind the tiles.Variation: If the tile only has a small hairline crack in it, you do not need to remove it at all. Apply a thin coat of clear caulk to the hairline crack to seal out any water that might get into it.

steps.headline: Place painter’s tape over the tile you want to remove.
steps.description: Lay overlapping strips across the surface of the tile to cover it completely. This will make it easier to drill and chisel into the tile without worrying about your tools slipping on the tile’s surface. You can also place painter’s tape over the surrounding tiles to protect them. If you do this, outline the tile you’re removing by drawing a line around it on the painter’s tape. This will help to prevent mistakes, such as drilling into a neighboring tile.

steps.headline: Drill holes through the middle of the tiles you need to remove.
steps.description: Drill 4 to 6 evenly spaced holes in the center of the tile with a ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) drill bit. This will make it easier to break up the tile without damaging any of the surrounding tiles. Be careful not to drill past the depth of the tiles, or the substrate and/or any waterproofing membrane may be damaged.

steps.headline: Hit the tile with a hammer to break it up into smaller pieces.
steps.description: Breaking the tile into smaller pieces will make it easier to remove it. Hit the tile at its center a few times with a hammer to break it up. If the tile is small or already cracked in several places, you might not need to do this. Be careful not to hit any of the adjoining tiles with the hammer. Aim for the center of the tile you need to remove.

steps.headline: Use a chisel to remove the tile pieces.
steps.description: Insert the end of the chisel into one of the holes you drilled into the tile. Then, turn the chisel so it is at a 45-degree angle to the tile. Hit the chisel with a hammer 3 to 5 times to break the tile up into smaller pieces. Repeat this for each of the holes you made in the tile. Pick up the larger broken pieces with gloved hands and use a dustpan and brush to sweep up any remaining fragments.

steps.headline: Remove the thinset mortar behind the tile you have removed.
steps.description: Use your chisel and hammer to do this. Place the chisel at a 45-degree angle to the thinset and then hit the chisel with the hammer to break it up. Don’t skip this part! Otherwise, the new tile will be higher up than the neighboring tiles. You can also check to see if you’ve removed enough of the thinset by placing the replacement tile into the space dry. See if it is even with the neighboring tiles. If it’s not even with them, you’ll need to keep chiseling until it is.

steps.headline: Check the waterproof membrane for damage before proceeding.
steps.description: Look for signs of water damage, such as swelling or a soft texture when you poke the membrane. If this area is damaged, you may need to remove all of the tiles and replace the backing along with the shower tiles. However, as long as the membrane is not damaged, you can proceed without replacing it.

steps.headline: Apply thinset tile cement to the substrate and back of the tile.
steps.description: Mix the thinset according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Then, use a notched trowel to spread the thinset across the area where the new tile will sit. Also, spread thinset in the center of the new tile on its backside. This will help it to adhere better. For small tile repairs, you may have to use a putty knife to apply the thinset.

steps.headline: Push the tile into the thinset firmly so it is bedded in the material.
steps.description: Press it down on all sides to ensure that it is secure in the space. Make sure the joints around the tile are uniform, and the surface of the newly installed tile is flush with the surrounding tiles. If the tile is lower than the other tiles, use more thinset. If it’s higher up, scrape some away and recheck the height of the tile. If the tile is on the ground, you can use a level to check it. Place the level on the tile and look at it to see if it is even. You may want to use tile spacers if you are installing more than one new tile.

steps.headline: Wait for the tile adhesive to dry 2-3 hours and grout the joints.
steps.description: Mix up the grout so it is the consistency of peanut butter. Then, use a rubber float to push the grout into the joints surrounding any new tiles you have installed. Use the rubber grout float to scrape the excess grout off the surface of the tiles as well. Hold the float at a 45-degree angle to the tiles and move it back and forth. Use unsanded grout if the tiles are spaced less than ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) apart or sanded grout if they are more than  ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) apart.

steps.headline: Clean the tiles with a sponge and water after 15 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Scrub all surfaces of the tile with the sponge and rinse the sponge after each wipe across the tile. Once the grout has dried and cured, it is difficult to remove, so it’s necessary to clean the tile right away.Tip: You can also buff the surface of the tile with a microfiber cloth after 60 minutes, if desired. Rub the cloth over the tile using small circular motions for about 30 to 60 seconds. This will leave the surface of the tile looking shiny, so it’s a great way to finish up your project.

steps.headline: Wait 24 hours for the grout to cure.
steps.description: This is the amount it will take before it’s safe to use the shower again without washing away any of the grout. To play it safe, you might even want to wait 36 to 48 hours before using the shower.
